ACI support windows 2019 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/container-instances/container-instances-faq

Yes you are right but as the microsoft documentation states Virtual Nodes can be scheduled only with Linux pods and nodes. I think the reason is related to the nature of Container Groups in ACI. Particularly about multi-container groups that are supported only on Linux machines.
This means one container group can support more linux container instances but only one windows container.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/container-instances/container-instances-container-groups

discussion.content: It’s A, because that’s scaling the nodes, https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/aks/cluster-autoscaler#about-the-cluster-autoscaler. Not B, is scaling pods. Not D, Virtual nodes are only supported with Linux pods and nodes, https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/aks/virtual-nodes.

Question itself should be deprectaed and removed from Az 305. But Answer is correct. 

AKS supports Ubuntu 22.04 and Azure Linux 2.0 as the node operating system (OS) for clusters with Kubernetes 1.25 and higher. Ubuntu 18.04 can also be specified at node pool creation for Kubernetes versions 1.24 and below.

AKS supports Windows Server 2022 as the default operating system (OS) for Windows node pools in clusters with Kubernetes 1.25 and higher. Windows Server 2019 can also be specified at node pool creation for Kubernetes versions 1.32 and below. Windows Server 2019 is being retired after Kubernetes version 1.32 reaches end of life (EOL) and isn't supported in future releases. 

https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs/blob/main/articles/aks/cluster-configuration.md#os-configuration

Selected Answer: D
Node autoscaler takes minutes to spin a new node.
Virtual nodes take seconds to provision a pod.
The key here is fast.

By default, the horizontal pod autoscaler checks the Metrics API every 30 seconds
By default, the cluster autoscaler checks the Metrics API server every 10 seconds

I would take A as the answer

It should be A.

Virtual Nodes don't support Linux. There is a workaround but should not be considered as native feature . NOT D.

C obviously NOT.

Both Cluster and horizontal pod autoscale are working. 

As per,
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/aks/concepts-scale#:~:text=default-,Cluster%20autoscaler,10.x%20or%20higher,-Cluster

[If your application needs to rapidly scale, the horizontal pod autoscaler may schedule more pods than can be provided by the existing compute resources in the node pool. If configured, this scenario would then trigger the cluster autoscaler to deploy additional nodes in the node pool, but it may take a few minutes for those nodes to successfully provision and allow the Kubernetes scheduler to run pods on them.]

Therefore directly go to Cluster Autoscale minimize the time.
came in exam on 20-sep-21, I passed, I choose given one

Virtual nodes are only supported with Linux pods and nodes. - so, not D.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/aks/virtual-nodes

The cluster autoscaler watches for pods that can't be scheduled on nodes because of resource constraints. The cluster then automatically increases the number of NODES.
Answer is A -- Increasing/scaling nodes
The horizontal pod autoscaler uses the Metrics Server in a Kubernetes cluster to monitor the resource demand of pods. If an application needs more resources, the number of PODS is automatically increased to meet the demand.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/aks/cluster-autoscaler

questions.question_text:
You have an Azure subscription.
You need to deploy an Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) solution that will use Windows Server 2019 nodes. The solution must meet the following requirements:
✑ Minimize the time it takes to provision compute resources during scale-out operations.
✑ Support autoscaling of Windows Server containers.
Which scaling option should you recommend?

choices.D: Virtual nodes with Virtual Kubelet ACI

questions.answer_description:
App Service not only adds the power of Microsoft Azure to your application, such as security, load balancing, autoscaling, and automated management. You can also take advantage of its DevOps capabilities, such as continuous deployment from Azure DevOps, GitHub, Docker Hub, and other sources, package management, staging environments, custom domain, and TLS/SSL certificates.
Key features of App Service include:
✑ Containerization and Docker - Dockerize your app and host a custom Windows or Linux container in App Service.
✑ Scale up or out manually or automatically. Host your apps anywhere in Microsoft's global datacenter infrastructure, and the App Service SLA promises high availability.
App Service can also host web apps natively on Linux for supported application stacks. It can also run custom Linux containers (also known as Web App for
Containers).
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/app-service/overview

✑ Scale-out automatically based on demand.
✑ Minimize administrative effort and costs.
What should you include in the recommendation?

discussion.content: Answers are correct

routing method is Traffic manager for sure (2nd drop down also gives the answer away too)

configuration is priority since "available to users if an Azure region is unavailable"

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/traffic-manager/traffic-manager-routing-methods#priority-traffic-routing-method

 If the primary endpoint isn't available, Traffic Manager routes the traffic to the second endpoint. In a situation where the primary and secondary endpoints aren't available, the traffic goes to the third, and so on.

questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Modify the Azure Traffic Manager routing
Azure Traffic Manager supports six traffic-routing methods to determine how to route network traffic to the various service endpoints.
Box 2: Endpoint monitor settings in the Azure Traffic Manager
Azure Traffic Manager includes built-in endpoint monitoring and automatic endpoint failover. This feature helps you deliver high-availability applications that are resilient to endpoint failure, including Azure region failures.
To configure endpoint monitoring, you must specify the following settings on your Traffic Manager profile: Protocol, Port, Path, custom header settings, etc.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/traffic-manager/traffic-manager-routing-methods https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/traffic-manager/traffic-manager-monitoring

Box 1: An on-premises data gateway
For logic apps in global, multi-tenant Azure that connect to on-premises SQL Server, you need to have the on-premises data gateway installed on a local computer and a data gateway resource that's already created in Azure.
Box 2: A connection gateway resource
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/connectors/connectors-create-api-sqlazure

Please ignore my previous comment. I go with On-Premises Data Gateway.
Hybrid Connection is for App Services.
On-Premises Data Gateway is for Logic Apps.
You can install it on another server on the same network that has internet access, like having a WAP server but in reverse.

You have an Azure subscription named Subscription1 that is linked to a hybrid Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) tenant.
